page.title: 11WILDLIFE 2
page.content: growth is protected by a kind of moss, known to the huntsman as 'velvet'. This shields the horn in the growing period, but as the horn matures, the covering irritates and the stag gets rid of it by rubbing its head against trees. Once this protection has gone it is only then that the horn becomes bone hard. In the growing stage a stag's horns are quite soft. It is a rule of Exmoor Forest that whoever finds a pair of horns may keep them. There are some magnificent specimens of deer to be found on Exmoor some of the finest weighing perhaps 350 pounds.
